linkTarget.anchoringText: The numerical model consists of a grid of squared-shape cells extracted from an existing dynamic model covering a part of the South area, as illustrated in Figure 1.

image-wrap.label: Figure 1
image-wrap.caption: Location map of the existing dynamic model

formatted-caption.caption-text: Location map of the existing dynamic model

linkTarget.anchoringText: The cells dimensions are 32.5 ft by 32.5 ft horizontally, and the layers are between 1 ft and 2 ft thick in the reservoir zone. As can be seen in Figure 2, the model represents only the layers 1 (20-ft thick) and 2 (40-ft thick) of the Upper Sand but not the layers of the Lower Sand. In accordance with the existing model from which the sector was extracted, five different rock-types populate the grid, namely:

image-wrap.label: Figure 2
image-wrap.caption: Vertical cross-section of the simulation grid

formatted-caption.caption-text: Vertical cross-section of the simulation grid

linkTarget.anchoringText: This curve reflects the reduction in water mobility versus polymer concentration or the increase in water viscosity versus polymer concentration. This mobility reduction curve will be validated using lab data once available. For the simulation work that is presented in this study, the curve displayed in Figure 3 was used based on previous experience considering a salinity and temperature of 30 g/L and 90°F, respectively.

image-wrap.label: Figure 3
image-wrap.caption: Mobility reduction curve

formatted-caption.caption-text: Mobility reduction curve

linkTarget.anchoringText: The first one is called the "IFT curve" which represents the evolution of the IFT versus the surfactant concentration. Based on previous experience, the curve displayed in Figure 4 represents the targeted performance of a reservoir-optimised surfactant formulation and was therefore used in this study. It can be noticed from Figure 4 that a target IFT value of 10−3 dyne/cm is reached for surfactant concentrations greater than 350 ppm.

image-wrap.label: Figure 4
image-wrap.caption: Interfacial tension curve

formatted-caption.caption-text: Interfacial tension curve

linkTarget.anchoringText: The relative permeability data were extracted from the original dynamic model and are displayed in Figure 5 (curves in plain line) for the main rock-type (RT1 - clean sand).

image-wrap.label: Figure 5
image-wrap.caption: Relative permeability curves depending on the capillary number

formatted-caption.caption-text: Relative permeability curves depending on the capillary number

linkTarget.anchoringText: Since the South and South-West areas of the RQLF field are still at an early stage of development, it was possible to investigate different well configurations so that an efficient development plan involving chemical EOR is identified. At first a 90m-spaced inverted 5-spot pattern was tested as illustrated on Figure 6.

image-wrap.label: Figure 6
image-wrap.caption: Inverted 5-spot pattern

formatted-caption.caption-text: Inverted 5-spot pattern

linkTarget.anchoringText: Before the water breakthrough that is shown in Figure 7, the injection rate is plateauing at around 100 bpd when injecting chemical-free water. After the water breakthrough, from 2018 onwards, the injection rate is smoothly increasing up to 600 bpd because water is recycled. In the reservoir, the sweep is not efficient at all and water preferential paths are observed. A cross-sectional view of water saturation in the simulation grid is presented in Appendix 2.

image-wrap.label: Figure 7
image-wrap.caption: Waterflood scenario using the 90mspaced inverted 5- spot pattern. Evolution of the water injection rate and the water cut

formatted-caption.caption-text: Waterflood scenario using the 90mspaced inverted 5- spot pattern. Evolution of the water injection rate and the water cut

linkTarget.anchoringText: Polymer dissolution in the injected water increases water viscosity and makes it harder to inject. This is reflected by the decrease in the water injection rate during polymer flooding down to 33 bpd as shown in Figure 8. While the sweep efficiency is increased in the reservoir as reflected by the decrease in the production watercut, the overall effect of the polymer remains unpromising using an inverted 5-spot pattern.

image-wrap.label: Figure 8
image-wrap.caption: Polymer flood scenario on the 90m- spaced inverted 5-spot pattern. Water injection rate (in bpd) and water cut for the best scenario (dashed line) compared to the waterflood scenario (continuous line)

formatted-caption.caption-text: Polymer flood scenario on the 90m- spaced inverted 5-spot pattern. Water injection rate (in bpd) and water cut for the best scenario (dashed line) compared to the waterflood scenario (continuous line)

linkTarget.anchoringText: Additional investigation showed that injectivity is not only caused by a relatively low maximum injection pressure, but is additionally a consequence of low fluid outtake. As illustrated in Figure 9, the injection rate follows the liquid production rate. This means that increasing the liquid production rate (outtake) would increase the water injection rate through voidage replacement.

image-wrap.label: Figure 9
image-wrap.caption: Liquid production rate and water injection rate for the waterflood case simulated on the inverted 5-spot pattern

formatted-caption.caption-text: Liquid production rate and water injection rate for the waterflood case simulated on the inverted 5-spot pattern

linkTarget.anchoringText: Following the first set of simulation runs using an inverted 5-spot pattern, improved well configurations were envisioned to increase the fluid outtake rate in order to increase the injected volumes through voidage replacement. Two types of well configurations were investigated as shown in Figures 10 and 11 including:

image-wrap.label: Figure 10
image-wrap.caption: Well configurations using vertical wells

formatted-caption.caption-text: Well configurations using vertical wells

linkTarget.anchoringText: Following the first set of simulation runs using an inverted 5-spot pattern, improved well configurations were envisioned to increase the fluid outtake rate in order to increase the injected volumes through voidage replacement. Two types of well configurations were investigated as shown in Figures 10 and 11 including:

image-wrap.label: Figure 11
image-wrap.caption: Well configurations using horizontal wells

formatted-caption.caption-text: Well configurations using horizontal wells

linkTarget.anchoringText: As shown in Table 2, the final recovery for the waterflood case varies by approximately 1% only with all the studied patterns using vertical wells. Nonetheless, as illustrated on the right of Figure 12, when improved inverted patterns are used less injected water volume is needed to reach the same recovery factor. This effect is relatively more pronounced when an inverted 7-spot pattern is used.

image-wrap.label: Figure 12
image-wrap.caption: Waterflood recovery factor versus time and cumulative injected volume of water for the inverted 5-, 9- and 7-spot patterns

formatted-caption.caption-text: Waterflood recovery factor versus time and cumulative injected volume of water for the inverted 5-, 9- and 7-spot patterns

linkTarget.anchoringText: As depicted in Figure 13, by plotting the best polymer flood scenario for each pattern, it is observed that polymer injection decreases the speed of oil recovery during the first years of simulation relative to when polymer-free water is injected. This is due to the decrease in the injection rates caused by the increased viscosity of the water. For the reservoir of interest, the difference between the reservoir and the maximum accepted injection pressures is relatively small (190 psi) and this restricts water injection at high rates especially with dissolved polymer.

image-wrap.label: Figure 13
image-wrap.caption: Polymer flood recovery factor versus time and cumulative injected volume of water for the inverted 5-, 9- and 7-spot patterns

formatted-caption.caption-text: Polymer flood recovery factor versus time and cumulative injected volume of water for the inverted 5-, 9- and 7-spot patterns

linkTarget.anchoringText: Figure 14 shows that, relative to the polymer flood cases that are shown in Figure 13, the surfactantpolymer flood scenarios lead to a less significant decrease in the rate of recovery when compared with the corresponding waterflood base cases. This is due to surfactant presence which increases water mobility and injectivity by modifying the water relative permeability.

image-wrap.label: Figure 14
image-wrap.caption: Surfactant-polymer flood recovery factor versus time and cumulative injected volume of water for the inverted 5-, 9- and 7-spot patterns

formatted-caption.caption-text: Surfactant-polymer flood recovery factor versus time and cumulative injected volume of water for the inverted 5-, 9- and 7-spot patterns

linkTarget.anchoringText: The inverted 7-spot pattern results were found to be more promising than those from the inverted 9-spot pattern. Figure 15 presents oil recovery versus cumulative water injection and clearly shows that, relative to waterflooding, polymer and surfactant-polymer injection can significantly increase oil recovery for a given volume of injected water.

image-wrap.label: Figure 15
image-wrap.caption: Efficiency curves of the waterflood, polymer (3000 ppm) and surfactantpolymer( 3000 ppm for both chemicals) flood scenarios for the inverted 7-spot pattern

formatted-caption.caption-text: Efficiency curves of the waterflood, polymer (3000 ppm) and surfactantpolymer( 3000 ppm for both chemicals) flood scenarios for the inverted 7-spot pattern

linkTarget.anchoringText: The impact of pattern area was investigated for the pattern that resulted in the highest recovery factor which is the inverted 7-spot pattern. Three different spacing values were tested as illustrated in Figure 16. It should be noted that the previously reported results for the 7-spot pattern were based on a spacing of 80 m.

image-wrap.label: Figure 16
image-wrap.caption: Inverted 7-spot pattern with different pattern areas

formatted-caption.caption-text: Inverted 7-spot pattern with different pattern areas

linkTarget.anchoringText: Figures 17 and 18 present efficiency curves to show the relationship of the recovery factor and cumulative water injection for the polymer scenario (at a polymer concentration of 2000 ppm) and the surfactant-polymer scenario (at polymer concentration of 3000 ppm and a surfactant concentration of 2000 ppm) using the three above-mentioned pattern sizes. It can be noticed from Figures 17 and 18 that the pattern size barely impacts the efficiency curves as those curves seem to be exactly superimposed with varying pattern sizes. Nonetheless, the pattern size severely impacts the final recovery factor obtained after 20 years of simulation by influencing injection capacity.

image-wrap.label: Figure 17
image-wrap.caption: Efficiency curve of the polymer flood scenario (injection at 2000 ppm) for the different areas of the inverted 7-spot pattern

formatted-caption.caption-text: Efficiency curve of the polymer flood scenario (injection at 2000 ppm) for the different areas of the inverted 7-spot pattern

linkTarget.anchoringText: Figures 17 and 18 present efficiency curves to show the relationship of the recovery factor and cumulative water injection for the polymer scenario (at a polymer concentration of 2000 ppm) and the surfactant-polymer scenario (at polymer concentration of 3000 ppm and a surfactant concentration of 2000 ppm) using the three above-mentioned pattern sizes. It can be noticed from Figures 17 and 18 that the pattern size barely impacts the efficiency curves as those curves seem to be exactly superimposed with varying pattern sizes. Nonetheless, the pattern size severely impacts the final recovery factor obtained after 20 years of simulation by influencing injection capacity.

image-wrap.label: Figure 18
image-wrap.caption: Efficiency curve of the surfactantpolymer flood scenario (injection at 3000 ppm of surfactant and 3000 ppm of polymer) for the different areas of the inverted 7-spot pattern

formatted-caption.caption-text: Efficiency curve of the surfactantpolymer flood scenario (injection at 3000 ppm of surfactant and 3000 ppm of polymer) for the different areas of the inverted 7-spot pattern

linkTarget.anchoringText: This economic indicator is expressed in US dollars (cost of chemicals only) per additional barrel of oil relative to waterflooding. Although it does not account for capital investment, this indicator gives a preliminary idea about the economic feasibility of different chemical flooding scenarios. For example, Figure 19 presents a plot showing the relationship between the final recovery factor and the abovementioned economic indicator for the EOR scenarios that were simulated using the 80m-spaced inverted 7-spot pattern.

image-wrap.label: Figure 19
image-wrap.caption: Overview of the EOR scenarios using the 80m-spaced inverted 7-spot pattern

formatted-caption.caption-text: Overview of the EOR scenarios using the 80m-spaced inverted 7-spot pattern

image-wrap.caption: Relative Permeability Endpoints Variation

formatted-caption.caption-text: Relative Permeability Endpoints Variation
